item.title: Orange rivers and melting glaciers: federal report shows rapid change in the Arctic
item.description: This year's Arctic Report Card from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration finds that the northernmost part of the Earth is warming faster than the global average, leading to melting glaciers, shifting fish populations, and rivers running orange.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: A very cute native critter — the fisher — has been officially spotted in Ohio for the first time in over a century
item.description: An animal not seen in Ohio in over a century, the fisher, has been spotted on a local wildlife camera. The sighting has raised hopes that the native mammal is naturally returning to the state.

item.title: What to know about death cap mushrooms, blamed for poisonings in California
item.description: Death cap mushrooms look harmless, but are responsible for the majority of the world's mushroom-related deaths. California officials say 21 people have been sickened in recent weeks, one fatally.

item.title: Experts warn White House's budget cuts could make tsunami warnings less reliable
item.description: In Alaska, a federal grant that funded seismic data collection in order to warn people about tsunamis is being cancelled. Experts say cuts like this could make tsunami warnings less reliable.

item.description: India's olive ridley turtle numbers appear to have rebounded after years of patchwork efforts to stem their decline. Can it last?

item.title: Fire prompts evacuations at U.N. climate talks in Brazil; 13 suffer smoke inhalation
item.description: Officials say a fire that spread through pavilions being used for U.N. climate talks in Brazil has prompted evacuations on the next-to-last day of the conference.
